title: House appropriators offer support to threatened NASA missions
summary:
House appropriators offered support, but no specific funding, for several NASA missions slated for cancellation in the administration’s 2026 budget proposal.
The post House appropriators offer support to threatened NASA missions appeared first on SpaceNews.

summary:
Italian startup Astradyne has secured €2 million in seed funding to accelerate the development of its Solar-Z product, a lightweight solar array designed to enhance the capabilities of small satellites. Astradyne was founded in 2021 with the aim of developing an off-the-shelf deployable solar array for small satellites that is lighter, more compact, and more […]

title: Eutelsat opens OneWeb ground stations to Earth observation with Ka-band boost
summary:
Eutelsat has teamed up with French satellite connectivity startup Skynopy to offer Earth observation operators spare capacity on the ground stations used for OneWeb, its LEO broadband service.

title: House Passes FY2026 NDAA
summary: The House passed the FY2026 National Defense Authorization Act this evening, authorizing funding for the U.S. Space Force and other components of the Department of Defense.  Only a fraction of […]
detailed_news: The House passed the FY2026 National Defense Authorization Act this evening. Only a fraction of the amendments offered to the NDAA were allowed to be debated on the floor. One that was not cleared would have overturned a requirement in the reconciliation bill to move a space vehicle — likely the Space Shuttle Discovery — from Virginia to Houston.

title: Mars Samples Must Be Returned To Earth to Prove If Life Existed There
summary: A rock sample discovered by NASA’s Mars Perseverance Rover last year may hold proof that life once existed on Mars, but scientists need to get the sample back to Earth […]
detailed_news: A rock sample discovered by NASA’s Mars Perseverance Rover may hold proof that life once existed on Mars. The finding that the sample shows the best evidence so far of past microbial life on the Red Planet was revealed last year and published today in Nature. Analysis by more sophisticated tools in laboratories here on Earth is the only way to be absolutely certain. How to do Mars Sample Return more cost effectively and on a shorter time frame remains unclear. Eight companies replied to NASA’s request for ideas last year, but none were sufficient for NASA to make a decision before the change in administrations. Earlier problems and budget uncertainty forced JPL to lay off 13 percent of its workforce in 2024.

title: NASA Unveils Potential Evidence of Ancient Martian Life in Peculiar Rock Patterns
summary:
An international team of scientists has revealed that unusual leopard-spot patterns on a Martian rock…
The post NASA Unveils Potential Evidence of Ancient Martian Life in Peculiar Rock Patterns appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: An international team of scientists has revealed that unusual leopard-spot patterns on a Martian rock may hold clues to ancient microbial life on the Red Planet. The rock, dubbed Cheyava Falls, was discovered by NASA’s Perseverance rover in June 2024 within the ancient river valley of Neretva Vallis. Cheyava Falls is among the youngest sedimentary rocks analyzed by Perseverance. This challenges earlier assumptions that biosignatures would only survive in formations far older than those currently known. This has reignited discussions about NASA’s Mars Sample Return (MSR) mission, which aims to bring Martian rocks back to Earth.

title: NASA highlights potential evidence of past life in Martian rock
summary:
Scientists have found potential evidence of past life on Mars in a rock sample collected by a NASA rover, even as a proposed budget cancels plans to return those samples.
The post NASA highlights potential evidence of past life in Martian rock appeared first on SpaceNews.

title: NASA Uses Colorado Mountains for Simulated Artemis Moon Landing Course
summary: NASA has certified a new lander flight training course using helicopters, marking a key milestone in crew training for Artemis missions to the Moon. Through Artemis, NASA explore the lunar South Pole, paving the way for human exploration farther into the solar system, including Mars.  The mountains in northern Colorado offer similar visual illusions and […]
detailed_news: NASA has certified a new lander flight training course using helicopters. The course is a key milestone in crew training for Artemis missions to the Moon. Through Artemis, NASA explore the lunar South Pole, paving the way for human exploration farther into the solar system, including Mars. The NASA-focused course has been in development since 2021. NASA will send astronauts to explore the Moon for scientific discovery, economic benefits, and to build the foundation for the first crewed missions to Mars. NASA explores the unknown in air and space, innovates for the benefit of humanity, and inspires the world through discovery. For more information about Artemis visit: https://www.nasa.gov/artemis.

title: Live coverage: SpaceX attempts to launch Indonesian communications satellite following back-to-back weather scrubs
summary: The launch once again faces long odds with poor weather in the forecast for a third day in a row. SpaceX is targeting liftoff from pad 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station at 8 p.m. EDT (0000 UTC).
detailed_news: Possible technical issues got in the way of a launch attempt Wednesday evening after back-to-back days of weather delays. The Nusantara Lima (N5) satellite will be sent into a geosynchronous transfer orbit roughly 27 minutes after liftoff. The satellite is built on the same Boeing-built bus used on Intelsat’s IS-33e spacecraft, which suffered an anomaly in 2024.

title: The Earth Observer Editor’s Corner: July–September 2025
summary: NOTE TO READERS: After more than three decades associated with or directly employed by NASA, Steve Platnick [GSFC—Deputy Director for Atmospheres, Earth Sciences Division] stepped down effective August 8, 2025. Steve began his civil servant career at GSFC in 2002, but his GSFC association went back to 1993, first as a contractor and then as […]
detailed_news: Steve Platnick stepped down effective August 8, 2025. Platnick played an integral role in the sustainability and advancement of NASA’s Earth Observing System platforms and data. NISAR will use two different radar frequencies to penetrate clouds and forest canopies. Combining data from these two radars will allow researchers to systematically and globally map Earth. The radar reflector will be used to direct and receive microwave signals from the two radars. By interpreting the differences between the L-band and S-band measurements, researchers will be able to discern characteristics about the surface below. As NISAR passes over the same locations twice every 12 days, scientists can evaluate how those characteristics have changed over time. The OCO mission hasn’t just about been about data and hardware. The human stories woven through the mission’s successes and setbacks are really what holds the mission together. OCO-3 extends the global CO 2 measurement record while adding new capabilities made possible by being on ISS. GEDI’s lasers have been operating nominally and the mission has continued to produce high-quality observations. The 2025 GEDI Science Team Meeting (STM) brought together the mission science team, competed science team. Compton J. Tucker retired from NASA in March 2025 after 48 years of public service. He was among 149 newly elected members to the National Academy of Sciences.  Compton's research achievements and all of the other scientific awards and honors received throughout his career. NASA explores the unknown in air and space, innovates for the benefit of humanity, and inspires the world through discovery, says Barry Lefer Associate Director of Research, Earth Science Division.

title: Summary of the 11th ABoVE Science Team Meeting
summary: Introduction The NASA Arctic–Boreal Vulnerability Experiment (ABoVE) is a large-scale ecological study in the northern regions of North America (Alaska and western Canada) that was developed to understand environmental changes in the region and the implications of those changes for society. Funded primarily by the NASA Terrestrial Ecology Program, this 10-year campaign has included field, […]
detailed_news: The NASA Arctic–Boreal Vulnerability Experiment (ABoVE) is a large-scale ecological study in the northern regions of North America. ABoVE deployed in three phases: 1) ecosystem dynamics (2015–2018); 2) ecosystem services (2017–2022); and 3) analysis and synthesis (2023–present) Now in the last year of the third phase, the Science Team (ST) consists of 67 active NASA-funded projects. Leads for the thematic working groups (WG) presented synthetic overviews of the research efforts of their group members. Following these presentations, breakout groups convened to discuss future activities of the WGs. Short summaries of each presentation are available below. Goetz reviewed the meeting goals and objectives. The Hydrology–Permafrost–Wetlands WG focused on the processes controlling changes in permafrost distribution and properties. The Disturbance Working Group WG leads presented their decade-long perspective on disturbance-related research in the ABoVE domain. ASTM11 participants watched the film, “ Scotty Creek Research Community - The Spirit of Collaboration ,” about the SCRS. ABoVE participated in multiple strategies to communicate research results to the public. ABoVE continued collaborating through knowledge exchange with early-career researchers and interns. ASTM11 featured 41 research posters across three sessions, organized by thematic area. Table 1 below provides all the project titles, presenter names, and links to each project and presentation. The UAF Arctic Research Open House was an opportunity for ST members and the public to explore the wide range of research happening at UAF. Many of the ABoVE collaborators were able to present at ASTM11. The UAF Alaska Fire Science Consortium, Bureau of Land Management Alaska Fire Service, and local artist Klara Maisch collaborated to develop the Wildfire Walk. A series of presentations on the overall structure and outcomes of ABoVE were held during ASTM11. Ryan Pavlick provided details on the NISAR mission, which launched after the meeting on July 30, 2025. A Career Trajectory panel featured Jennifer Watts, Jonathan Wang, Brendan Rogers, and Xiaoran “Seamore” Zhu. Klara Maisch discussed her work creating science-informed artwork through interdisciplinary collaborations.  ASTM11 brought together an interdisciplinary team for a final team meeting that showcased the many accomplishments made over the past decade. The group outlined current gaps and needs in Arctic and boreal research and discussed possibilities for future NASA terrestrial ecology campaigns. While this was the last meeting of this ST, research for some projects will continue into 2026.

title: NASA Invites Media to View Artemis Moon Rocket, Spacecraft at Kennedy
summary: Media are invited to see NASA’s fully assembled Artemis II SLS (Space Launch System) rocket and Orion spacecraft in mid-October before its crewed test flight around the Moon next year.   The event at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida will showcase hardware for the Artemis II lunar mission, which will test capabilities needed for […]
detailed_news: Media are invited to see NASA’s fully assembled Artemis II SLS (Space Launch System) rocket and Orion spacecraft. Artemis II will send NASA astronauts Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover, Christina Koch, and CSA (Canadian Space Agency) astronaut Jeremy Hansen on an approximately 10-day journey around the Moon and back.

title: NASA Data, Trainings Help Uruguay Navigate Drought
summary: When Uruguay faced its worst drought in nearly a century, the nation’s water authority turned to NASA satellite data and trainings to build a reservoir-monitoring tool.
detailed_news: NASA satellite data and trainings helped Uruguay create a drought-response tool that its National Water Authority now uses to monitor reservoirs. A similar approach could be applied in the United States and other countries around the world. From 2018 to 2023, Uruguay experienced its worst drought in nearly a century. The analysis prevented actions that might have wasted important resources. Rain began to refill Uruguay’s reservoirs, allowing the country to declare an end to the water crisis. Though the immediate water crisis has passed, the tool Pohren created will be useful in the future in Uruguay and around the world.

title: NASA Says Mars Rover Discovered Potential Biosignature Last Year
summary: A sample collected by NASA’s Perseverance Mars rover from an ancient dry riverbed in Jezero Crater could preserve evidence of ancient microbial life. Taken from a rock named “Cheyava Falls” last year, the sample, called “Sapphire Canyon,” contains potential biosignatures, according to a paper published Wednesday in the journal Nature. A potential biosignature is a […]
detailed_news: A sample collected by NASA’s Perseverance Mars rover from an ancient dry riverbed in Jezero Crater could preserve evidence of ancient microbial life. The sample, called “Sapphire Canyon,” contains potential biosignatures, according to a paper published Wednesday in the journal Nature. “This finding by Persevereance, launched under President Trump in his first term, is the closest we have ever come to discovering life on Mars," says acting NASA Administrator Sean Duffy. The discovery was particularly surprising because it involves some of the youngest sedimentary rocks the mission has investigated. An earlier hypothesis assumed signs of ancient life would be confined to older rock formations. This finding suggests that Mars could have been habitable for a longer period or later in the planet’s history than previously thought.

title: NASA Aims to Keep Fuel Cool Under Pressure with Zero Boil-Off Experiment On NG-23
summary: Space missions rely on cryogenic fluids — extremely cold liquids like liquid hydrogen and oxygen — for both propulsion and life support systems. These fuels must be kept at ultra-low cryogenic temperatures to remain in liquid form; however, solar heating and other sources of heat increase the rate of evaporation of the liquid and cause […]
detailed_news: NASA's Zero Boil-Off Tank Noncondensables (ZBOT-NC) experiment will launch aboard Northrop Grumman’s 23 rd resupply mission to the International Space Station. The investigation will operate inside the Microgravity Science Glovebox aboard the space station to gather data on how NCGs affect volatile liquid behavior in microgravity. NASA is a private, nonprofit organization based in Washington, D.C. The agency's mission is to explore the unknown in air and space. It also aims to advance the fundamental scientific knowledge required to go farther and stay longer in space, while also benefitting life on Earth. For more information, visit NASA.gov.

title: Dinner is Served!
summary: Dinnertime fare on the International Space Station takes center stage in this Aug. 15, 2025, photo. One tray features shrimp cocktail on whole grain wheat crackers, while the other holds sushi made with seaweed, Spam, tuna, and rice. Both trays are secured with Velcro strips to keep them stable inside the Unity module’s galley. The […]
detailed_news: One tray features shrimp cocktail on whole grain wheat crackers, while the other holds sushi made with seaweed, Spam, tuna, and rice. Both trays are secured with Velcro strips to keep them stable inside the Unity module’s galley. Activity aboard the space station will inform long-duration missions like Artemis and future human expeditions to Mars.

The company's GEN-1 and GEN-2 demonstrators will likely be the smallest reentry capsules ever flown, comparable to picosatellites. title: Immense stellar jet in Milky Way outskirts
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: twin jets of hot gasses are blazing across eight light-years – twice the distance between our Sun and the nearest star system. Superheated gases falling onto the massive star are blasted back into space along the star’s rotational axis. Powerful magnetic fields confine the jets to narrow beams. NASA/ESA/CSA James Webb Space Telescope witnessed the spectacle in infrared light.

title: NASA’s Webb Observes Immense Stellar Jet on Outskirts of Our Milky Way
summary: A blowtorch of seething gasses erupting from a volcanically growing monster star has been captured by NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope. Stretching across 8 light-years, the length of the stellar eruption is approximately twice the distance between our Sun and the next nearest stars, the Alpha Centauri system. The size and strength of this particular […]
detailed_news: The stellar jet is located in a nebula known as Sharpless 2-284 (Sh2-284 for short) Streaking across space at hundreds of thousands of miles per hour, the outflow resembles a double-bladed dueling lightsaber from the Star Wars films. Central protostar, weighing as much as ten of our Suns, is located 15,000 light-years away in the outer reaches of our galaxy. Webb’s new images are telling us that the formation of massive stars in such environments could proceed via a relatively stable disk around the star. “Once we found a massive star launching these jets, we realized we could use the Webb observations to test theories of massive star formation.” For more than 30 years, astronomers have disagreed about how massive stars form.

title: What Would It Take to Say We Found Life? We Asked a NASA Expert: Episode 63
summary: What Would It Take to Say We Found Life? We call this the podium test. What would it take for you personally to confidently stand up in front of an international audience and make that claim? When you put it in that way, I think for a lot of scientists, the bar is really high. […]
detailed_news: What would it take for you to confidently stand up in front of an international audience and make that claim? What we see might depend a lot on where we look. Carl Sagan once said, “Life is the hypothesis of last resort,” meaning that we ought to work hard for such a claim to rule out alternative possibilities. Space missions rely on cryogenic fluids — extremely cold liquids like liquid hydrogen and oxygen. A blowtorch of seething gasses erupting from a volcanically growing monster star has been captured. NASA explores the unknown in air and space, innovates for the benefit of humanity.

The agency previously announced this event as a teleconference.  Watch the news conference on NASA’s YouTube channel and the agency’s […]
detailed_news: NASA will host a news conference at 11 a.m. EDT Wednesday to discuss the analysis of a rock sampled by the agency’s Perseverance Mars rover last year. The sample, called “Sapphire Canyon,” was collected in July 2024 from a set of rocky outcrops on the edges of Neretva Vallis.

title: Live coverage: Space Development Agency, SpaceX to launch next-gen national security satellites
summary: The 21 satellites from York Space Systems are the first in the SDA’s Tranche 1 Transport Layer satellite constellation. SpaceX is targeting liftoff from pad 4 East at Vandenberg Space Force Base at 7:12 a.m. PDT (10:12 a.m. EDT / 1412 UTC).
detailed_news: SpaceX is targeting launch of its Falcon 9 rocket for the Tranche 1 Transporter Layer mission from Space Launch Complex 4 East at 7:12 a.m. PDT. The 21 satellites, built by York Space Systems, are the first, fully operational spacecraft for the constellation known as the Proliferated Warfighter Space Architecture (PWSA) This mission was awarded to SpaceX as part of the National Security Space Launch (NSSL) Phase 2 contract. York Space Systems announced the completion of its first 21 T1TL satellites back in April 2025. The Transport Layer is a type of “relay’ that helps extend sensitive, tactical communications beyond a line of sight. There are 10 launches planned for Tranche 1, which include six within the Transport Layer and four within the Tracking Layer.

title: SpaceX’s $17 Billion Spectrum Coup: Securing Starlink’s Direct-to-Cell Revolution
summary:
In a monumental transaction, SpaceX has allocated more than $17 billion—nearly equivalent to 75% of…
The post SpaceX’s $17 Billion Spectrum Coup: Securing Starlink’s Direct-to-Cell Revolution appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX has allocated more than $17 billion to secure exclusive radio spectrum rights from established satellite firm EchoStar. This strategic acquisition promises to lock in SpaceX’s preeminence in worldwide satellite communications for the foreseeable future. Equipped with its expansive satellite fleet and the forthcoming transition of Starship from its test program into an operational phase, SpaceX is primed to deploy vast network capabilities into low Earth orbit. The deal is worth $17 billion. It equips forthcoming Starlink Direct-to-Cell satellites with 20-fold throughput gains. This unlocks comprehensive 5G mobile service with performance akin to “comparable” ground-based LTE. Paired with earthly 5G setups, Starlink could vanquish all coverage gaps on the planet.

title: After early struggles, NASA’s ambitious mission to Titan is “on track” for launch
summary: "Probably the best part of my day is watching that team hit their milestones."
detailed_news: NASA's Dragonfly mission to fly across the surface of Titan is delayed and over budget. But the fault is due to the space agency's management rather than the program itself. The cost of the mission has soared from an initial figure of $850 million upon its selection in 2019 to $3.35 billion today. Dragonfly will explore impact craters where water may have existed in liquid form for thousands of years. Areas of Titan, in the wake of impacts, would be much like a primordial Earth when life started here billions of years ago. This will be NASA's first landing on another ocean world, with the primary objective of searching for the chemical building blocks of life.

title: NASA Partnerships Allow Artificial Intelligence to Predict Solar Events
summary: Exploring AI in space bolsters analytics software used in finance, manufacturing, and industry.
detailed_news: The Frontier Development Lab of Mountain View, California, is an ongoing partnership between NASA and commercial AI firms to apply advanced machine learning to problems that matter to the agency and beyond. The same solar activity that makes auroras can cause disruptions to satellites that are essential to systems on Earth. By importing several datasets monitoring the ionosphere, solar activity, and Earth’s magnetic field, the researchers were able to predict disruptive events 24 hours in advance.

Armstrong Operations and Checkout Building at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Monday, Aug. 11, 2025. […]

Join the Artemis II mission and sign up to launch your name aboard the Orion spacecraft and SLS (Space Launch System) rocket alongside the crew.

title: Ami Choi: Unraveling the Invisible Universe
summary: Research Astrophysicist and Roman’s Deputy Wide Field Instrument Scientist – Goddard Space Flight Center From a young age, Ami Choi — now a research astrophysicist at NASA — was drawn to the vast and mysterious. By the fifth grade, she had narrowed her sights to two career paths: marine biology or astrophysics.  “I’ve always been […]
detailed_news: Ami Choi is a research astrophysicist at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center. She helped lay the groundwork for the Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope. Choi operates at the intersection of engineering, calibration, and cosmology. She's especially drawn to so-called systematics, which are effects that can alter signals. Choi encourages staying curious, being persistent, and taking opportunities to get involved in research. “You don’t have to be perfect at math or physics right away,” she said. ‘What matters most is a deep curiosity and the tenacity to keep pushing through.’

title: NASA Study: Celestial ‘Accident’ Sheds Light on Jupiter, Saturn Riddle
summary: An unusual cosmic object is helping scientists better understand the chemistry hidden deep in Jupiter and Saturn’s atmospheres — and potentially those of exoplanets. Why has silicon, one of the most common elements in the universe, gone largely undetected in the atmospheres of Jupiter, Saturn, and gas planets like them orbiting other stars? A new […]
detailed_news: The Accident is a brown dwarf, a ball of gas that’s not quite a planet and notquite a star. The Accident has a perplexing mix of physical features, some of which have been previously seen in only young brown dwarfs and others seen only in ancient ones. Among several surprises, they found evidence of a molecule they couldn’t initially identify. The study authors surmise it is because far less oxygen was present in the universe when the ancient brown dwarf formed. The available silicon would have bonded with hydrogen instead, resulting in silane. Brown dwarfs are often easier to study than gas giant exoplanets because the light from a faraway planet is typically drowned out by the star.

title: Finnish Satellite Manufacturer ReOrbit Closes €45M Series A
summary:
Finnish satellite manufacturer ReOrbit has closed a €45 million Series A funding round, part of which will be used to expand its manufacturing capacity. Founded in 2019, ReOrbit manufactures a range of small Earth observation and communications satellites for both civil and defence applications. Prior to its Series A, the company’s most recent round was […]
The post Finnish Satellite Manufacturer ReOrbit Closes €45M Series A appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Finnish satellite manufacturer ReOrbit has closed a €45 million Series A funding round. Part of the funding will be used to expand its manufacturing capacity. The round is one of the largest in the European space tech sector. It surpasses The Exploration Company’s €40 million series A and falls just short of Look Up’S €50 million round.

title: The business case for resting among the stars
summary:

title: Crossroads to the Future – NASA Stennis Grows into a Model Federal City
summary: NASA’s Stennis Space Center is widely known for rocket propulsion testing, especially to support the NASA Artemis program to send astronauts to the Moon to prepare for future human exploration of Mars. What may not be so widely known is that the site also is a unique federal city, home to more than 50 federal, […]
detailed_news: NASA’s Stennis Space Center is widely known for rocket propulsion testing. The site is home to more than 50 federal, state, academic, and commercial tenants. It is also a model of government efficiency and a powerful economic engine for its region. “NASA Stennis is a remarkable story of vision and innovation,” Center Director John Bailey said. On June 14, 1974, NASA Administrator James Fletcher announced the south Mississippi location would be renamed National Space Technology Laboratories. There still were many developments to come, including the first space shuttle main engine test and the subsequent 34-year test campaign. However, even in this period of early development, one thing was clear – the future lay ahead and NASA Stennis was on its way.

title: Launch Your Name Around Moon in 2026 on NASA’s Artemis II Mission
summary: Lee este comunicado de prensa en español aquí. NASA is inviting the public to join the agency’s Artemis II test flight as four astronauts venture around the Moon and back to test systems and hardware needed for deep space exploration. As part of the agency’s “Send Your Name with Artemis II” effort, anyone can claim their […]
detailed_news: NASA is inviting the public to join the agency’s Artemis II test flight. Four astronauts will venture around the Moon and back to test systems and hardware needed for deep space exploration. Anyone can claim their spot by signing up before Jan. 21. The collected names will be put on an SD card loaded aboard Orion before launch.

title: NASA Stennis Provides Ideal Location for Range of Site Tenants
summary: If location, location, location is the overarching mantra in real estate, it is small wonder that NASA’s Stennis Space Center is considered a national asset and prime aerospace and technology operations site. It has long stood as a premier – and the nation’s largest – rocket propulsion test site. With unparalleled test infrastructure and expertise, […]
detailed_news: NASA’s Stennis Space Center is considered a prime aerospace and technology operations site. NASA Stennis is the choice location for a range of agencies, organizations, offices, and companies. For Relativity Space, the “unparalleled infrastructure” at NASA St Dennis has been key to enabling its rocket engine testing. The National Data Buoy Center was the very first NASA Stennis federal city tenant, arriving onsite in September 1970. Various Navy functions eventually located continuing operations onsite, including the Naval Meteorology and Oceanography Command, the Naval Oceanographic Office, and the Navy Office of Civilian Human Resources. The U.S. Department of Homeland Security credits the “high-quality, secure, and resilient” NASA St Dennis site for its decision to location information technology and applications operations on site.
